title: Question 14
prompt:
Brett repeats her plea to Jake, “Don’t get drunk,” four times. What affect does this repetition have?

The repetition shows that
description: Click the <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
When Jake first starts quickly drinking his wine, Brett immediately tells him not to get drunk: “Don’t get drunk, Jake,” she said. “You don’t have to.” Jake’s first response appears defensive: “How do you know?” Since he doesn’t stop drinking, she tells him again to stop: “Don’t,” she said. “You’ll be all right.” Jake’s second response is that he is not really getting drunk. He denies that he is drinking to get drunk, but Brett doesn’t believe him. She wants him to stop, so she tells him twice not to drink. Finally, Jake gives in to her by suggesting that they go out. Brett will not stop pleading with Jake or listen to his excuses. She is adamant that he must stop drinking.


“I’m not getting drunk,” I said. “I’m just drinking a little wine. I like to drink wine.”

“Don’t get drunk,” she said. “Jake, don’t get drunk.”

“Want to go for a ride?” I said. “Want to ride through the town?”
